title: What would the night sky look like if there was no time delay from the light travelling to earth? - Quora

response.answer_text: This would imply a universe with an infinite speed of light, and thus no principle of locality. Locality is so ingrained in the laws of physics that it’s unlikely any such self-consistent universe could exist, and so there wouldn’t be any night sky to observe. A closely related question, though, is what if the universe were infinitely old and static, so that the light from all stars in the universe had had time to reach you? To answer that question, you can make a couple of interesting observations about stars in the sky: A star’s brightness attenuates with the square of its distance.A star’s angular area in the sky decreases by the square of its distance.Combine those two facts and you’ll come to the really cool conclusion that a star’s areal intensity is constant, and doesn’t depend on distance. In an infinitely old and static universe, where approximately infinite stars have had time for their light to reach Earth, every line of sight in Earth’s sky would end on a star. And so, from the areal intensity argument above, the entire night sky should be at least as bright[1] as the surface of a star. The fact that it isn’t is known as Olbers’ paradox, and was one of the early arguments against an infinitely old, static, universe. [1] Note that every star in such a universe is also absorbing heat from every star within its line of sight, and so we’d expect additional brightening due to that fact.

If light had infinite velocity then that would mean there would be no boundary to the observable universe. The night sky would be bright white because you’d be able to see light from every star in the Univese. If the Universe is infinite then there would be no direction in which there isn’t eventually a star. If the Universe isn’t infinite, but only very, very, very, very large, then there would still be no direction in which there isn’t eventually a star due to the Universe wrapping back around on itself. The night sky would be no different than the day sky. We’d never be able to investigate the early Universe, in fact we’d never even know there WAS a Universe beyond Earth. The sky would just be white all the time. I’m not sure if we’d see the moon or not, so there might be something we’d be interested in.
